marketNews.title: BI Rate Cut Following Trump's Reduction of Indonesian Tariffs
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia decided to cut the BI Rate by 25 bps to 5.25% today, Wednesday (16/7), with the deposit facility and lending facility also cut by 25 bps each to 4.5% and 6% respectively. Before this announcement, the Bloomberg consensus expectation was split, with 55% expecting the BI Rate to remain unchanged and 45% expecting a 25 bps cut. Bank Indonesia Governor, Perry Warjiyo, explained that the decision considered: 1) inflation and core inflation projections for the next 2 years remaining low below the target midpoint of Â± 2.5%; 2) stability of the Rupiah exchange rate; and 3) efforts to encourage economic growth. Bank Indonesia maintained its economic growth target in the range of +4.6-5.4% YoY for 2025, which had previously been downgraded twice this year. Bank Indonesia noted that banking credit growth slowed to +7.77% YoY in 1H25 (vs. 5M25: +8.43% YoY), marking the weakest growth since June 2023 and lower than the 2025 target which had been downgraded by Bank Indonesia to the range of +8-11% YoY. This result was pressured by banking preference to place liquid funds in securities and a cautious stance in distributing credit. Nevertheless, Perry stated that his side still maintains the 2025 banking credit growth target in the range of +8-11% YoY, driven by expectations of improvement in 2H25 following the trade agreement with the US. Perry mentioned that trade uncertainty is slowly subsiding as the tariffs imposed by the US for Indonesian products drop from the previous level of 32% to 19%. Perry stated that lower interest rates could boost credit growth, while the tariff agreement with the US is expected to help businesses make future business decisions. Regarding the newly announced tariff reduction, the Secretary of the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs, Susiwijono Moegiarso, told Bloomberg that the government is preparing a joint statement with the US which will detail additional information regarding this agreement. Here are the key points in the trade agreement, according to the US President's explanation, Donald Trump: 1. Indonesia will not impose import tariffs or non-tariff barriers on goods from the US. 2. Indonesia also agreed to import energy from the US worth 15 billion US dollars, US agricultural products worth 4.5 billion US dollars, and 50 Boeing aircraft. However, the time frame for the agreement to import goods from the US is still unknown. 3. Trump added that if there is transshipment from a country with higher tariffs, then those tariffs will be added to the tariffs paid by Indonesia.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: Responding to these 2 developments, the Rupiah exchange rate weakened -0.11% to the level of 16,278, while the 10-year government bond yield was flat at 6.573% in today's trading, Wednesday (16/7). Meanwhile, the IHSG strengthened +0.7% to the level of 7,192, but this was more due to the significant rise of 2 large market cap stocks, namely DCII (+19.99%) and DSSA (+3.86%). The big banks were mixed with slight increases/decreases below 2%. The muted market movement is potentially caused by investor assessment that the developments above have a relatively limited impact on the outlook for the Indonesian economy, especially with the details regarding market access granted to the US in exchange for tariff reductions still unavailable. We assess that convincing improvement signs in economic indicators are needed before foreign investors become more interested in Indonesia.

marketNews.title: Other hot information you need to know...
marketNews.content: 1. Bank Indonesia noted that banking credit growth slowed to +7.77% YoY in 1H25 (vs. 5M25: +8.43% YoY), marking the weakest growth since June 2023 and lower than the 2025 target downgraded by Bank Indonesia to the range of +8-11% YoY. Based on usage, investment credit in 1H25 grew +12.53% YoY (vs. 5M25: +13.74% YoY), while consumption credit was +8.49% YoY (vs. 5M25: +8.82% YoY) and working capital was +4.45% YoY (vs. 5M25: +4.94% YoY). Meanwhile, Sharia financing in 1H25 grew +8.37% YoY (vs. 5M25: +9.19% YoY) and MSME credit growth reached +2.18% YoY (vs. 5M25: +2.17% YoY). 2. Deputy Minister of Finance, Anggito Abimanyu, stated that the Ministry of Finance is reviewing the expansion of excise objects by adding processed food products high in sodium (P2OB) - such as packaged snacks - as new excise goods in the 2026 fiscal year. In addition to P2OB, the Ministry of Finance is also reviewing the imposition of excise on a number of other commodities, such as plastic, fuel oil (BBM), packaged sweetened beverages (MBDK), as well as the conversion of the luxury goods sales tax (PPnBM) scheme on motor vehicles to an excise scheme. 3. The US statistics bureau noted that US Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation reached 2.7% YoY in June 2025 (vs. May 2025: 2.4% YoY inflation), exceeding the consensus expectation of 2.6% YoY and marking the highest level since February 2025. On a monthly basis, US inflation reached 0.3% MoM (vs. May 2025: 0.1% MoM inflation), in line with consensus expectations and marking the largest increase in the last 5 months. Core inflation rose to 0.2% MoM and 2.9% YoY (vs. May 2025: 0.1% MoM and 2.8% YoY inflation), lower than the consensus expectation of 0.3% MoM monthly and in line with the consensus expectation annually. 4. US President, Donald Trump, stated on Tuesday (15/7) that he is most likely to impose import tariffs on pharmaceutical products as early as the end of July 2025. Trump said that pharmaceutical tariffs will start with low tariffs, before later increasing to the level of 200% after giving pharmaceutical companies 1 year to build factories in the US. Trump also mentioned that he will soon impose tariffs on imported semiconductor products, although he did not elaborate further. 5. Pefindo Economist, Suhindarto, stated that total Indonesian corporate bond issuance reached 90.9 trillion Rupiah during 1H25 (+48% YoY), with bonds and sukuk contributing 90.3 trillion Rupiah (+50% YoY) while the rest consisted of medium term notes and securitization. From the issuance purpose side, refinancing funds reached 31.5 trillion Rupiah (+107% YoY), while working capital issuance reached 56.3 trillion Rupiah (+46% YoY). Suhindarto mentioned that the maturity of corporate debt securities reaches 161 trillion Rupiah in 2025, with the majority maturing in 2H25. 6. Coordinating Minister for Food Affairs, Zulkifli Hasan, stated on Tuesday (15/7) that the launch of the Village Cooperative (Kopdes) Merah Putih will be postponed again from July 19, 2025, to July 21, 2025, on the grounds that relevant officials can attend and listen directly to President Prabowo Subianto's directives. Previously, the launch of Kopdes Merah Putih was postponed from July 12, 2025, because President Prabowo still had other agendas abroad. Deputy Minister of Cooperatives, Ferry Juliantono, stated that the initial financing for Kopdes Merah Putih will be channeled through a special KUR facility with a ceiling of up to 3 billion Rupiah per cooperative.

tickerNews.title: TPIA Clarifies Rumor of JV Plan to Acquire Exxon Gas Station Business
tickerNews.content: TPIA: Chandra Asri Pacific stated in a clarification to the IDX that there is no definitive agreement regarding the rumor of the company's joint venture that is reportedly planning to acquire Exxon Mobil's gas station business in Singapore. Nevertheless, TPIA stated that the company is always open to existing opportunities in order to support the company's business performance to continue growing sustainably. TPIA's clarification emerged after Bloomberg last week reported that Aster Chemicals and Energy - a joint venture between TPIA and Glencore - was in talks to buy Exxon Mobil's gas station business in Singapore. Bloomberg sources stated that Aster is finalizing the details of the agreement, including price and transaction structure.

tickerNews.title: DATA and its subsidiary signed a working capital facility with BCA
tickerNews.content: DATA: Remala Abadi together with its subsidiary, PT PC 24 Cyber Indonesia, signed a working capital facility of up to 250 billion Rupiah with Bank Central Asia (BBCA), where this facility has a tenor of 1 year.

tickerNews.title: MTEL and TBIG Deny Rumors of Merger Plan
tickerNews.content: MTEL: Dayamitra Telekomunikasi stated in a clarification to the IDX that the company has no information regarding the rumor of a merger plan with Tower Bersama Infrastructure (TBIG). Nevertheless, MTEL stated that the company always evaluates various strategic options to respond to developments in the telecommunications industry in order to create the best value for all company shareholders. In a separate clarification, TBIG stated that the company is unaware of information related to the rumored merger plan with MTEL, and as of now, no agreements or documents related to this corporate action have been signed. MTEL's and TBIG's clarifications emerged after Bloomberg last week reported that MTEL was reconsidering merging with TBIG, after the previous plan failed in 2015.

tickerNews.title: WIKA Records New Contract Value of IDR 4.3 Trillion in 1H25
tickerNews.content: WIKA: Wijaya Karya Corporate Secretary, Ngatemin, told Kontan that the company recorded a new contract value of 4.3 trillion Rupiah during 1H25 (-58% YoY). The new contracts were dominated by the industrial sector at 58.86%, followed by infrastructure and buildings (34%), and EPC and property (7.14%).

tickerNews.title: CGAS Obtains Government Confirmation for Gas Allocation from Galian Field
tickerNews.content: CGAS: Citra Nusantara Gemilang announced that it has received a letter from the government regarding the determination of the allocation and utilization of natural gas from the Galian Field, Pertamina EP Zone 7 Working Area. In the determination letter, the daily submission amount reaches 1.5 MMSCFD and the total contract amount reaches 4,110 MMSCF. CGAS explained that this allocation determination is the initial stage of preparing for the implementation of the Galian Karawang LNG Station project, in line with the utilization purpose of the IPO funds.
